I don't know of a formal comparison, or of any other systems in use with 
Heritrix-centric workflows.

The WARC writing of recent Heritrix releases already leverages the info 
left in the CrawlURI by the Persist[Log|Store|Load]Processor + 
FetchHistoryProcessor mechanism to write 'revisit' records instead of 
full 'response' records, when appropriate.

We're using the Persist[Log|Store|Load]Processor + FetchHistoryProcessor 
mechanism on a number of production crawls at IA, writing WARCs. We'll 
continue to maintain and improve this approach, and the 
'continuous/adaptive' functionality coming after 2.2 will assume WARCs 
as the usual content format.

A recent version of BerkeleyDB added the ability for multiple 
'environments' (disk database directories) to efficiently share the same 
cache space, so carrying-forward the data from a previous crawl will be 
easier in the future: there will be a single environment directory which 
contains just the URI dup-reduction data, which can be reused for future 
crawls. (Now, you either use a PersistLogProcessor log which must be 
imported to the new crawl's 'state' environment, or use the 
PersistStoreProcessor and share forward the whole 'state' environment, 
which is bloated with other unnecessary info.)

- Gordon @ IA
